batting_exercises.name: Rotational Medicine Ball Throws
batting_exercises.equipment: Medicine ball or slightly weighted ball
how_to: Stand sideways to a wall or partner, feet shoulder-width apart.
Hold the ball at hip height with both hands.
Rotate your hips and trunk explosively and throw the ball into the wall or to a partner.
Catch or retrieve the ball, reset your stance and repeat on the same side, then switch sides.
benefits: Increases bat swing speed by improving hip and core rotation.
Builds explosive power used in lofted and power hitting shots.

prescriptions.notes: Use a very light ball. Focus on smooth rotation and technique, not maximum power.
Moderate intensity. Quality of each throw more important than speed.
Explosive intent. Overweight players should stop if any back or knee discomfort appears.
High-intensity power work. Only for experienced and conditioned players.
Lower volume to protect joints and back. Focus on controlled movement.

safety_notes: Always perform after a full-body warm-up.
Avoid aggressive twisting if there is any lower back pain.
Use lighter balls for younger or weaker players.

batting_exercises.name: Bat Swing Overload Training
batting_exercises.equipment: Weighted bat, bat with resistance bands, or slightly heavier training bat
how_to: Stand in your normal batting stance without a ball.
Use a slightly heavier bat or attach light resistance to your normal bat.
Play a full aggressive swing as if hitting a six, keeping your head still and balance strong.
Control the follow-through and avoid over-rotating or losing balance.
Rest briefly between swings and between sets.
benefits: Develops swing-specific strength for power hitting.
Improves ability to clear the boundary with less effort.

prescriptions.notes: Use only a slightly heavier bat. Never sacrifice technique.
Moderate to high intensity. Great for developing finishing power.
High workload. Only for players with good shoulder and back health.
Lower volume to reduce fatigue and joint stress.
Focus on slow, controlled swing path rather than maximum power.

safety_notes: Do not use a bat that is too heavy – small overload is enough.
Stop if you feel sharp pain in shoulder, elbow or lower back.
Younger players should first master normal bat swing mechanics.

batting_exercises.name: Core Plank Variations
how_to: Hold a front plank position on elbows or hands, keeping body in a straight line.
For side planks, lie on your side and support your body on one elbow and the side of one foot.
Maintain controlled breathing and avoid letting hips sag or rise.
benefits: Improves trunk stability for controlled shot-making.
Supports lower back during long innings and high-intensity training.

prescriptions.reps: 20–25 seconds front plank, 10–15 seconds side plank each side
prescriptions.notes: Younger players should focus on holding good shape rather than maximum time.

prescriptions.reps: 25–30 seconds front plank, 15–20 seconds side plank each side
prescriptions.notes: Can mix front and side planks within each set.

prescriptions.reps: 30–40 seconds front plank, 20–25 seconds side plank each side
prescriptions.notes: Solid base-building for senior cricket workload.

prescriptions.reps: 40–45 seconds front plank, 25–30 seconds side plank each side
prescriptions.notes: Can add small variations (leg lifts, arm lifts) if control is excellent.

prescriptions.reps: 15–25 seconds front plank, 10–15 seconds side plank each side
prescriptions.notes: Shorter holds, longer rest to protect lower back and shoulders.

safety_notes: Maintain neutral spine – do not let the lower back arch excessively.
If unable to hold full plank, start from knees or incline (hands on bench or wall).

batting_exercises.name: Sprint Shuttle Runs (20 m)
batting_exercises.equipment: Two cones or markers 20 metres apart
how_to: Place two cones or marks on the ground around 20 metres apart.
Sprint from one cone to the other at a strong but controlled pace.
Walk slowly back to the start as active recovery.
Maintain good running form: slight forward lean, relaxed shoulders, high knee drive.
benefits: Improves running between wickets (quick singles and turning for second runs).
Builds cricket-specific aerobic and anaerobic conditioning.

prescriptions.notes: Keep intensity at about 70–80%, focus on rhythm and safe turning.
Match the kind of effort needed for match running between wickets.
High-quality efforts, good for building repeat sprint ability.
Match-intensity simulation. Not for beginners in fitness.
Advanced conditioning. Use cautiously in-season to avoid overload.
Shorter volume, prioritise safe movement and controlled pace.
Use as a gentle conditioning tool, not maximum intensity.

safety_notes: Avoid doing sprints on very hard, uneven or slippery surfaces.
Warm up hamstrings and calves thoroughly beforehand.
Stop if there is any sharp pain in hamstring, calf, knee or Achilles.

batting_exercises.name: Grip & Forearm Strength Holds
batting_exercises.equipment: Hand gripper / light dumbbell / towel hold
how_to: Hold gripper or light dumbbell in batting hand.
Squeeze and maintain a firm hold without shaking.
Alternate between both hands for equal strength development.
benefits: Improves bat face control and reduces late-shot error.
Strengthens wrists for placement and 360° scoring.

prescriptions.notes: Use very light grip tension, avoid full contraction.
Focus on quality endurance, not maximum force.
Should feel controlled muscular fatigue.
Grow forearm endurance for long batting innings.
Too long holds may stress elbow joints.

safety_notes: Avoid gripping too hard causing joint strain.
Stop if tingling in fingers occurs (nerve compression sign).

batting_exercises.name: Bodyweight Squats and Reverse Lunges
how_to: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart.
Perform squats keeping chest up and knees aligned.
Reverse lunges: step one leg back, lower hips, return to start.
benefits: Improves balance and stability for front-foot batting.
Builds quad & glute strength for power transfer.

prescriptions.notes: Very slow tempo, technique priority.
Control knee alignment and foot stability.
Intermediate strength volume.
High volume lower-body conditioning.
Avoid knee valgus → go slow.

safety_notes: Keep knees from collapsing inward.
Stop if knee pain or hip clicking occurs.

batting_exercises.name: Skipping Rope Footwork Conditioning
how_to: Jump lightly on balls of feet.
Keep jumps small and rhythmic.
Land softly to protect joints.
benefits: Improves fast footwork for spin & pace.
Strengthens ankle mobility and calf elasticity.

prescriptions.notes: Keep landings soft.
Avoid high bounce; knee stress risk.

safety_notes: Not recommended for knee pain or achilles injury.
Use cushioning shoes.

batting_exercises.name: Agility Ladder In–Out & Lateral Footwork
how_to: Perform in–out steps rhythmically.
Maintain low center of gravity.
Use short, fast steps.
benefits: Improves movement to pitch of ball.
Develops lateral stability & batting stance reaction.

prescriptions.notes: Technique before speed.
Control joints.

safety_notes: Keep ladder stable.
Do not sprint blindly.

batting_exercises.name: Pallof Press Anti-Rotation Core
how_to: Stand side-on to band anchor.
Press band forward resisting rotation.
benefits: Improves trunk stability during power swings.
Reduces collapse during leg-side shots.

prescriptions.notes: Avoid trunk strain.

safety_notes: Keep rib cage down.
Avoid leaning backwards.

batting_exercises.name: Push-Up Progression Strength
how_to: Maintain straight body line.
Elbows 45° to torso.
Lower chest slowly, push explosively.
benefits: Shoulder & tricep strength for bat speed.
Scapular control reduces injury.

prescriptions.notes: Can do from knees.
Wall push-ups recommended until strong.

safety_notes: Avoid elbow flare.
Stop if wrist pain occurs.

batting_exercises.name: Single-Leg Balance & Reach
how_to: Stand on one foot.
Reach forward slowly keeping balance.
Switch legs after reps.
benefits: Improves weight transfer in shots.
Strengthens stabilizers for late adjustments.
safety_notes: Wall support allowed for kids.
Avoid twisting knee inward.

batting_exercises.name: Dynamic Batting Warm-Up Circuit
how_to: Arm circles.
Hip circles.
Shadow batting swings.
T-spine trunk rotations.
benefits: Warms joints & improves range of motion.
Prevents muscle strain in batting.
safety_notes: Never skip warm-up.
Keep shoulder movements smooth, not jerky.
